body:
### Problem

This is very similar to #29037 and might be the same.

I was opening a 587MB restic log file and after a few seconds neovim would crash with one of these:
1. `realloc(): invalid next size`
2. `malloc(): invalid next size (unsorted)`
3. `corrupted size vs. prev_size`

there might be more.

Disabling the `copilot.lua` plugin does seem to circumvent the issue.

Unfortunately it seems this depends a lot on my full setup and the stacktraces seem to have gaps in them.
A `find / -xdev -ls > large_file` + 'nvim large_file` seems to also trigger the issue, maybe it will on other machines also.

Maybe this is just a luajit issue?

What I can provide next or do to help?


Details:
neovim from Arch (extra) with astronvim and a bunch of plugins.

```
NVIM v0.10.1
Build type: Release
LuaJIT 2.1.1723675123
```

Backtraces:
1.`realloc(): invalid next size`
```

#7  0x00007633cdcbda15 in __GI___libc_realloc (oldmem=0x5a2f33193660, bytes=16368) at malloc.c:3508

#7  0x00007d2f372869b8 in _int_realloc (av=av@entry=0x7d2f373c9ac0 <main_arena>, oldp=oldp@entry=0x5fcc0a153fd0, oldsize=oldsize@entry=8192, nb=nb@entry=16384) at malloc.c:4969
#8  0x00007d2f37287a15 in __GI___libc_realloc (oldmem=0x5fcc0a153fe0, bytes=16368) at malloc.c:3508

```

### Steps to reproduce

1. Open a large text file, somewhere in the range of > 400MB
2. `:lua a = vim.json.encode(table.concat(vim.api.nvim_buf_get_lines(0, 1, -1, false), "\n"))`

### Expected behavior

no crash.

### Neovim version (nvim -v)

v0.10.1

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

unknown

### Operating system/version

Arch

### Terminal name/version

wezterm 20240722-080956-7e8fdc11

### $TERM environment variable

xterm-256color

### Installation

Arch (extra)

comment_data.body: Can you try the development version? The [Releases](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases/tag/nightly) page has pre-built archives for Linux/Windows/macOS. Check `:version` to confirm the version.

```
:version

NVIM v0.11.0-dev-700+gbcae8be91
Build type: RelWithDebInfo
LuaJIT 2.1.1724512491
```

```
#0  __pthread_kill_implementation (threadid=<optimized out>, signo=signo@entry=6, no_tid=no_tid@entry=0) at pthread_kill.c:44
#1  0x000070278b893463 in __pthread_kill_internal (threadid=<optimized out>, signo=6) at pthread_kill.c:78
#2  0x000070278b83a120 in __GI_raise (sig=sig@entry=6) at ../sysdeps/posix/raise.c:26
#3  0x000070278b8214c3 in __GI_abort () at abort.c:79
#4  0x000070278b822354 in __libc_message_impl (fmt=fmt@entry=0x70278b9b02f5 "%s\n") at ../sysdeps/posix/libc_fatal.c:132
#5  0x000070278b89d765 in malloc_printerr (str=str@entry=0x70278b9ae169 "realloc(): invalid next size") at malloc.c:5772
#6  0x000070278b8a1a04 in _int_realloc (av=av@entry=0x70278b9e4ac0 <main_arena>, oldp=oldp@entry=0x5c50483330f0, oldsize=oldsize@entry=16384, nb=nb@entry=32752) at malloc.c:4939
#7  0x000070278b8a2a15 in __GI___libc_realloc (oldmem=0x5c5048333100, bytes=bytes@entry=32736) at malloc.c:3508
#8  0x00005c4ffac42371 in strbuf_resize (s=s@entry=0x70278bb3b2c8, len=<optimized out>) at /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/src/cjson/strbuf.c:176
#9  0x00005c4ffac425f6 in strbuf_append_string (s=s@entry=0x70278bb3b2c8, str=0x5c4ffad9fde8 "\\/") at /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/src/cjson/strbuf.c:190
#10 0x00005c4ffac426aa in json_append_string (l=l@entry=0x70278bb26380, json=json@entry=0x70278bb3b2c8, lindex=lindex@entry=-1) at /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/src/cjson/lua_cjson.c:592
#11 0x00005c4ffac486b3 in json_append_data (l=l@entry=0x70278bb26380, cfg=cfg@entry=0x70278bb3adc8, current_depth=current_depth@entry=3, json=json@entry=0x70278bb3b2c8) at /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/src/cjson/lua_cjson.c:788
#12 0x00005c4ffac48c28 in json_append_object (l=l@entry=0x70278bb26380, cfg=cfg@entry=0x70278bb3adc8, current_depth=current_depth@entry=3, json=json@entry=0x70278bb3b2c8) at /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/src/cjson/lua_cjson.c:769
#13 0x00005c4ffac488e5 in json_append_data (l=l@entry=0x70278bb26380, cfg=cfg@entry=0x70278bb3adc8, current_depth=3, current_depth@entry=2, json=json@entry=0x70278bb3b2c8) at /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/src/cjson/lua_cjson.c:840
#14 0x00005c4ffac48c28 in json_append_object (l=l@entry=0x70278bb26380, cfg=cfg@entry=0x70278bb3adc8, current_depth=current_depth@entry=2, json=json@entry=0x70278bb3b2c8) at /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/src/cjson/lua_cjson.c:769
#15 0x00005c4ffac488e5 in json_append_data (l=l@entry=0x70278bb26380, cfg=cfg@entry=0x70278bb3adc8, current_depth=2, current_depth@entry=1, json=json@entry=0x70278bb3b2c8) at /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/src/cjson/lua_cjson.c:840
#16 0x00005c4ffac48c28 in json_append_object (l=l@entry=0x70278bb26380, cfg=cfg@entry=0x70278bb3adc8, current_depth=current_depth@entry=1, json=json@entry=0x70278bb3b2c8) at /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/src/cjson/lua_cjson.c:769
#17 0x00005c4ffac488e5 in json_append_data (l=l@entry=0x70278bb26380, cfg=cfg@entry=0x70278bb3adc8, current_depth=1, current_depth@entry=0, json=json@entry=0x70278bb3b2c8) at /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/src/cjson/lua_cjson.c:840
#18 0x00005c4ffac48d35 in json_encode (l=0x70278bb26380) at /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/src/cjson/lua_cjson.c:890
#19 0x00005c4ffacc1f96 in lj_BC_FUNCC ()
#20 0x00005c4ffacae1c6 in lua_pcall (L=L@entry=0x70278bb26380, nargs=nargs@entry=0, nresults=nresults@entry=0, errfunc=errfunc@entry=-2) at lj_api.c:1122
#21 0x00005c4ffaaecea1 in nlua_pcall (lstate=lstate@entry=0x70278bb26380, nargs=nargs@entry=0, nresults=nresults@entry=0) at /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/src/nvim/lua/executor.c:174
#22 0x00005c4ffaaf440d in nlua_schedule_event (argv=<optimized out>) at /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/src/nvim/lua/executor.c:372
#23 0x00005c4ffabe56b5 in state_handle_k_event () at /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/src/nvim/state.c:119
#24 0x00005c4ffab4c74a in nv_event (cap=0x7ffdd7be5b90) at /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/src/nvim/normal.c:6610
#25 0x00005c4ffab42640 in normal_execute (state=0x7ffdd7be5b20, key=<optimized out>) at /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/src/nvim/normal.c:1234
#26 0x00005c4ffabe553b in state_enter (s=0x7ffdd7be5b20) at /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/src/nvim/state.c:101
#27 0x00005c4ffab41040 in normal_enter (cmdwin=<optimized out>, noexmode=<optimized out>) at /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/src/nvim/normal.c:520
#28 0x00005c4ffab00522 in main (argc=3, argv=<optimized out>) at /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/src/nvim/main.c:661
```

What's next?

> What's next?

Find the plugin code that calls `vim.json.encode` (`json_encode`). That may give a hint about what's going on. I'm wondering if a plugin is trying to encode the entire 500MB file, or store it in a string variable.

How much memory does your system have? 

maybe try opening the buffer, then run:

    :lua a = vim.json.encode(vim.api.nvim_buf_get_lines(0, 1, -1, false))

but I couldn't reproduce the issue that way.
Could be LSP/LLM.

```
â¯ free -h
               total        used        free      shared  buff/cache   available
Mem:            62Gi        18Gi        30Gi       1.5Gi        18Gi        43Gi
Swap:           95Gi        11Gi        84Gi
```

It does seem like it is trying to json encode the whole file into a `text` property of some `jsonrpc` payload (lsp?).

I confirmed that having copilot lsp (`zbirenbaum/copilot.lua`) installed triggers the issue but not with a minimal config yet. I'll see if can I create something minimal but I'm not too sure how.
Then that is expected. The LSP protocol was built for typical source code, not webscale log files. If you regularly work with such files, you should configure LSP/Copilot _not_ to attach to them.

> Then that is expected. The LSP protocol was built for typical source code, not webscale log files

If it's our LSP client, we should detect this and fail gracefully. Do we have an open issue for that?
The crash looks to be in the cjson library, not our wrapper code; not sure how much we want to delve into that. @bfredl ?

I managed to trigger the issue with the output file of:
```
yes $(seq -s '' 100)|head -n 2000000 > large_file
```
More interesting would be a minimal way of triggering the crash in Neovim by just calling `vim.json.encode(payload)` (where `payload` is, e.g., just the contents of the file as a single string).

Somewhat minimal config that triggers the issue via `nvim large_file` (after plugin is installed, not first launch):
```
-- Bootstrap lazy.nvim
local lazypath = vim.fn.stdpath("data") .. "/lazy/lazy.nvim"
if not (vim.uv or vim.loop).fs_stat(lazypath) then
  local lazyrepo = "https://github.com/folke/lazy.nvim.git"
  local out = vim.fn.system({ "git", "clone", "--filter=blob:none", "--branch=stable", lazyrepo, lazypath })
  if vim.v.shell_error ~= 0 then
    vim.api.nvim_echo({
      { "Failed to clone lazy.nvim:\n", "ErrorMsg" },
      { out,                            "WarningMsg" },
      { "\nPress any key to exit..." },
    }, true, {})
    vim.fn.getchar()
    os.exit(1)
  end
end
vim.opt.rtp:prepend(lazypath)

-- Make sure to setup `mapleader` and `maplocalleader` before
-- loading lazy.nvim so that mappings are correct.
-- This is also a good place to setup other settings (vim.opt)
vim.g.mapleader = " "
vim.g.maplocalleader = "\\"

-- Setup lazy.nvim
require("lazy").setup({
  spec = {
    -- add your plugins here
    {
      "zbirenbaum/copilot.lua",
      cmd = "Copilot",
      event = "BufEnter",
      config = function()
        require("copilot").setup({ })
      end,
    },
  },
})
```

I don't think you need to have copilot auth'd for this to trigger.
can you try the code in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/30225#issuecomment-2324649142

Sorry for missing that.

```
:lua a = vim.json.encode(vim.api.nvim_buf_get_lines(0, 1, -1, false))
```
doesn't trigger the code path exactly the same but this 
```
:lua a = vim.json.encode(table.concat(vim.api.nvim_buf_get_lines(0, 1, -1, false), "\n"))
```
does, mostly.

I am was testing with the `--clean` argument on nvim.

It seems like `json_append_string()` must be called with a sufficiently large string and trigger a `strbuf->resize()` during the call for it to crash. If the `strbuf` was already large enough then it doesn't seem to trigger the issue. This can be simulated by running the original snippet first and then my modified version. 

With my full config I can also run the original snippet `:lua a = vim.json.encode(vim.api.nvim_buf_get_lines(0, 1, -1, false))` before enabling copilot and it seems to workaround the issue.

Thank you! Could you please edit the issue to add the copilot-free minimal repro?

Note that [lua-cjson](https://github.com/openresty/lua-cjson/) (which we vendor, and where the crash happens) has received a number of updates ([some of them looking related](https://github.com/openresty/lua-cjson/commit/2bfad8f5eeb821357d2ada29506e864ff7ec947e)) since we included it which we should look into backporting. @bfredl ?

(Future note: when vendoring, we should note not just upstream but also the last synced commit at the top of the file.)
Ye, adding it to the milestone for the backporting part.
Should this be handled as a security issue if it is triggering a buffer overflow in a vendored lib?
Only if it can demonstrably used for privilege escalation (above what you need to run Neovim on the target system in the first place). Random crashes are _not_ a CVE.
Can anybody here test #32114 and see if it fixes the issue?

Looks like it ðŸ‘ 

I repeated the steps from https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/30225#issuecomment-2325700767 on https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/32114/commits/7530afc647d505e735ea165715099081a2fb9148 and it didn't crash, whilst performing those steps on my system neovim (v0.10.3) does result in a crash originally documented in this issue.
Fixed by https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/32114.

labels.description: issue reporting a crash or segfault
labels.name: bug-crash

title: lua-cjson crash after opening large log file with LSP and/or Copilot
